title: Mexico for Foodies - 10 Days
subtitle: A Culinary Journey Through Mexico's Greatest Eating Regions
meta_title: Mexico Food Tour 10-Day Itinerary - Culinary Travel Guide 2025
meta_description: The ultimate 10-day Mexico food trip: Oaxaca's moles, Mexico City's world-class scene, Puebla's origins, and street food masterclass. A delicious journey through UNESCO-recognized cuisine.
hero_alt: Colorful Mexican tacos and traditional dishes
introduction: Mexican cuisine is UNESCO-recognized for good reason. This 10-day culinary journey takes you through the country's three greatest food regions: Oaxaca's ancient moles and mezcal, Mexico City's world-class restaurants and street food, and Puebla's culinary origins. You'll take cooking classes, explore markets, and eat your way through unforgettable meals.
best_time: Year-round; October-November for Día de Muertos food traditions
highlights: Learn to make seven moles in Oaxaca cooking class
Explore legendary markets (Benito Juárez, La Merced, San Juan)
Dine at world-renowned restaurants (Pujol, Casa Oaxaca)
Master street food: tacos, tlayudas, tortas, tamales
Discover mole poblano where it was born
Experience chocolate from cacao to cup

days.title: Arrival in Oaxaca
days.description: Arrive in Mexico's culinary capital. Oaxaca's food traditions are among the world's most complex and ancient. Get oriented, explore the centro, and start your journey with dinner at a top restaurant.
activities: Arrive Oaxaca airport (OAX) or bus from CDMX
Check in to hotel in Centro Histórico
Orientation walk: Zócalo, Santo Domingo, Alcalá pedestrian street
Chocolate at Mayordomo (watch grinding process)
Sunset mezcal at In Situ or Mezcaloteca
Dinner at Casa Oaxaca El Restaurante (reserve ahead)
tips: Book restaurant reservations before arriving
Start acclimating to spice levels gradually
Oaxaca is at altitude—stay hydrated

days.title: Markets & Cooking Class
days.description: Today is about understanding Oaxacan ingredients. Morning at the legendary markets, then a hands-on cooking class learning to prepare moles, the soul of Oaxacan cuisine.
activities: Early breakfast: Mercado 20 de Noviembre (tasajo, memelitas)
Market tour: Mercado Benito Juárez (chiles, cheese, chapulines)
Cooking class with market visit (reserve ahead)
Learn mole negro, coloradito, and traditional dishes
Enjoy your creations for late lunch
Rest and explore Jalatlaco neighborhood
Dinner at Itanoní (heirloom corn tortillas)
tips: Book cooking class 1-2 weeks ahead (La Casa de los Sabores, Seasons of My Heart)
Try chapulines (grasshoppers)—they're delicious
Mercado 20 de Noviembre's smoke section is essential

days.title: Mezcal Route & Village Food
days.description: Venture into mezcal country, visiting traditional palenques (distilleries) and artisan villages. Learn the difference between industrial and artisanal mezcal while sampling dozens of varieties.
activities: Join a mezcal route tour (essential for transportation)
Visit 2-3 traditional palenques
Learn about agave varieties (espadín, tobalá, etc.)
Taste artisanal mezcal made in clay pots
Lunch in Santiago Matatlán (mezcal capital)
Optional: Stop at artisan village (pottery, textiles)
Return to Oaxaca
Dinner at Los Danzantes (mezcal-paired dining)
tips: Don't drink and drive—book a tour
Artisanal mezcal is smooth, not harsh
Buy directly from producers for best prices and quality

days.title: Fly to Mexico City
days.description: Morning flight to Mexico City, the world's largest Spanish-speaking city and a culinary powerhouse. Settle into Roma or Condesa and dive into the street food scene.
activities: Morning flight Oaxaca to Mexico City (1 hour)
Check in to hotel in Roma Norte or Condesa
Late lunch: Street tacos (El Vilsito, Tacos Orinoco)
Walk Roma Norte architecture and food scene
Mezcal at Licorería Limantour or La Clandestina
Dinner at Rosetta (Italian-Mexican fusion) or Maximo Bistrot
tips: Roma and Condesa have Mexico City's best restaurant scene
Book top restaurants weeks ahead
Taco stands peak 9pm-midnight

days.title: Markets & Fine Dining
days.description: Experience the contrast between Mexico City's ancient markets and world-class fine dining. Morning at legendary La Merced and San Juan markets, evening at one of the World's 50 Best Restaurants.
activities: Early: La Merced Market (largest in the Americas)
Sample everything: fruits, juices, prepared foods
San Juan Market (gourmet/exotic ingredients)
Lunch at market stalls or Café de Tacuba
Rest and prepare for evening
Dinner at Pujol (book months ahead) or Quintonil
Tasting menu experience with mole madre
tips: Book Pujol 2-3 months in advance
La Merced is huge—go with a guide or focus on one section
San Juan has exotic meats (lion, crocodile) if you're adventurous

days.title: CDMX Cooking Class & Neighborhoods
days.description: Hands-on cooking class focusing on classic Mexican dishes, followed by exploration of neighborhoods and their signature foods.
activities: Morning cooking class (Mexican Home Cooking, Eat Mexico)
Learn salsas, tamales, or mole preparation
Lunch from your creations
Afternoon: Coyoacán neighborhood exploration
Market snacks at Coyoacán market
Churros at El Moro (since 1935)
Dinner at Contramar (seafood) or Eno
tips: Cooking classes book up—reserve early
Coyoacán churros at the market are legendary
Contramar is best for lunch but great anytime

days.title: Street Food Deep Dive
days.description: A full day devoted to street food mastery. From morning tacos to late-night tortas, experience the incredible diversity of Mexico City's street food culture.
activities: Morning: Tacos de canasta (basket tacos) in Centro
Mid-morning: Carnitas at Los Cocuyos
Lunch: Torta at Tortas Don Polo or La Casa de Toño for pozole
Afternoon break and digestive walk
Late afternoon: Taquería El Califa de León
Night: Tacos al pastor at El Huequito or El Vilsito
Optional: Late-night tacos after midnight
tips: Pace yourself—it's a marathon, not a sprint
Street food is safest at busy stands with high turnover
Follow the crowds—lines indicate quality

days.title: Day Trip to Puebla
days.description: Drive to Puebla, birthplace of mole poblano and chiles en nogada. This colonial city has its own distinct culinary identity worth exploring.
activities: Early drive to Puebla (2 hours)
Breakfast: Cemitas at Mercado El Carmen or 5 de Mayo
Explore Puebla's talavera pottery and colonial centro
Lunch at Meson Sacristía (traditional Poblano)
Try original mole poblano
Visit candy street (Calle de los Dulces)
Optional: Chiles en nogada if in season (Aug-Sept)
Return to CDMX for final night
tips: Cemitas are Puebla's signature sandwich—essential
Chiles en nogada available August-September only
The talavera pottery makes great souvenirs

days.title: Final Food Adventures
days.description: Last full day to fill in gaps, revisit favorites, and pick up food souvenirs. End with a memorable final dinner.
activities: Morning: Return to favorite spots or try something new
Visit La Merced or Mercado Roma for souvenirs
Buy: mole paste, dried chiles, chocolate, mezcal
Lunch at a missed must-try
Rest before final evening
Farewell dinner: Splurge at Sud 777 or return to favorite
Final mezcal at favorite bar
tips: Food souvenirs pack well—mole paste, dried chiles, chocolate
Mezcal has liquid limits for carry-on
Write down names of everything you loved

days.title: Departure
days.description: Final morning in Mexico. Squeeze in one last taco before heading to the airport.
activities: Final breakfast at hotel or neighborhood café
Pack food souvenirs carefully
Last taco if time allows
Transfer to airport
tips: Mexico City traffic is brutal—leave 2+ hours for airport
Declare food items at customs (most are allowed)
Start planning your return trip

practical_info.getting_there: Fly into Oaxaca (OAX) and out of Mexico City (MEX), or vice versa. Internal flight between cities is 1 hour.
practical_info.getting_around: Walking and Uber in cities. Tours for mezcal route and market visits. ADO bus for Puebla day trip or hire a driver.
what_to_pack: Stretchy pants (you will eat a lot)

faqs.question: Will I get sick from street food?
faqs.answer: Street food is generally safe, especially at busy stalls with high turnover. Start slow, let your stomach adjust, and avoid raw items the first few days. Busy stands with lines are your safest bet—freshness equals safety.

faqs.question: How do I book top restaurants?
faqs.answer: Pujol, Quintonil, and similar restaurants book 2-3 months ahead through their websites. Rosetta, Contramar, and mid-range restaurants take reservations 1-2 weeks out. Have your hotel help with bookings.

faqs.question: I'm vegetarian—will this work?
faqs.answer: Mexican cuisine is very meat-focused, but there are options. Markets have incredible produce, there are vegetarian-focused restaurants, and many dishes can be modified. Let cooking classes know in advance. You'll miss some experiences but still eat incredibly well.

faqs.question: How spicy is the food?
faqs.answer: Spice levels vary widely. Many dishes aren't spicy at all; heat comes from salsas added at the table. Start mild and work up. Ask 'no picante' if you're sensitive. Oaxaca tends to be less spicy than other regions.
